Sentencas: Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are attractive devices for combined power and heat generation because they can operate with a variety of fuels.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: Syngas (CO + H-2) is particularly attractive but many questions remain about its behavior on SOFC anodes including the relative oxidation efficiencies of CO and H-2 and tendency to form carbon deposits.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: In this report, operando spectroelectrochemical measurements, including infrared emission spectroscopy, near infrared thermal imaging, and vibrational Raman scattering, combined with spectrochronopotentiometry, are performed using anode-supported SOFCs operating with simulated syngas at 800 degrees C. Results quantify the fate of syngas over Ni-YSZ anodes in SOFCs related to their performance.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: SOFCs operating with simulated syngas mixtures are compared with those for H-2 and CO used separately.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: Thermal imaging shows more SOFC anode heating for H-2-rich syngas than for operating on CO or H-2 alone.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: We attribute this result to carbon gasification by water that is produced by H-2 oxidation.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels

Sentencas: Raman spectra together with spectrochronopotentiometry experiments illustrate that carbon is not observed on the anode surface at 800 degrees C - although it is at 750 degrees C and 700 degrees C - yet carbon is likely present in the spectroscopically inaccessible, electrochemically active region at the electrolyte-electrode interface.
Titulo: Operando optical studies of solid oxide fuel cells operating on CO and simulated syngas fuels
